What do you like most about nf-core?: Community maintenance
Engagement

What do you like most about nf-core?: The slack workspace to ask questions and get support!

What do you like most about nf-core?: It makes integrating other exiting pipelines into another pipeline easier, and using Nextflow means we don't need to port our pipelines to new cloud and server systems.
What have been your biggest difficulties: The documentation is generally poor. The underlying logic is not explained so more advanced operations take a long time to implement. The examples provided in the docs are often too simple for real world applications.

What do you like most about nf-core?: The community, and the shared effort to create high-quality and reproducible bioinformatic workflows.
What have been your biggest difficulties: Quick updates to the template and modules, breaking changes in Nextflow. Overall I think it's more good than bad, but can still be difficult.

What do you like most about nf-core?: Very good starting point to implement a pipeline for a certain technology / use
What have been your biggest difficulties: the ability to capture new necessities (new pipelineS) or improvements into current pipelines. This process is very cumbersome and is not effective for users
Any other feedback on nf-core?: It feels difficult to jump from user to occasional developer. The documentation and current standards-templates is very daunting.

What do you like most about nf-core?: The very high level of the community and its kindness
What have been your biggest difficulties: Learning how to deal CI-related stuffs when developing a new pipeline

What do you like most about nf-core?: Very easy for the user.  The pipeline launch page is awesome.
What have been your biggest difficulties: Life of the user is made easy at the expense of the developer's time. The Nextflow DSL is hard to memorise; the best strategy is cargo-culting from other files. Error messages are useless most of the times.

What do you like most about nf-core?: it's a very responsive community, you can get help on many topics related to the pipelines, modules and tools. There's a good atmosphere

Sometimes it's also difficult to collaborate to existing pipelines, but we can't add a new one due to some overlap.

What do you like most about nf-core?: Nextflow trainings, Bytesizes, Hackathons, and Nextflow Summit
What have been your biggest difficulties: None
Any other feedback on nf-core?: None

What do you like most about nf-core?: I think, there are some good policies in place. I like that collaboration on pipelines is enforced, rather than just being a pipeline repository collecting multiple different workflows for the same task.
What have been your biggest difficulties: Admittedly Nextflow. Why couldn't you build the same great community around a Pythonic workflow system? Also, I see the role of Seqera quite ambivalent. Yes, they are maintaining Nextflow and providing many resources for free (such as the containers), but are also clearly imposing some changes on the community with business interest in mind. Of course, other companies could contribute as well (and are not doing it much), but the dominance of Seqera (considering how many leading nf-core people are on their payroll) is clearly unhealthy from a community aspect.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Develop a sustainability strategy. What I mean by that: The incentives for developing a pipeline and getting it into nf-core are high. A new pipeline can be published, and nf-core creates exposure and provides a solid base to build on. However, like with every open source project, the maintenance is tedious, but usually not very glamorous. For some of the biggest nf-core pipelines, the lead developers have essentially resigned and taken over new tasks. That is fair. But it is also a problem, because whoever fills that gap can hardly write a new paper. The same goes for those that maintain the website or tools. I do not have a solution to that, but the problem will only get more pressing the older nf-core gets, so it would be good to start addressing it.
Comments James: We like Nextflow...? You can write new papers (but need more examples), fair enough better passing on docs

What do you like most about nf-core?: Reproducibility, Interchangeability of modules/pipelines, nf-tools as a convenient tool for almost every task with pipeline management/execution/...
What have been your biggest difficulties: Adopting nf-core to new domains
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Guidelines could be more precise. I often find myself in a situation where I'm not 100% sure how certain situations in pipeline development are handled.

What do you like most about nf-core?: reproducibility
What have been your biggest difficulties: standarisation

What do you like most about nf-core?: automation and reproducibility
What have been your biggest difficulties: unclear error messages
Any other feedback on nf-core?: better and clearer warnings and error messages

What do you like most about nf-core?: Friendliness, community feeling, and the pipelines work really well, which at the end of the day is the most important.
The application of common structure and patterns among different pipelines - when you learn one, it's easier and faster to get started with a different one.
What have been your biggest difficulties: Confusion when different pipelines are not equally developed - what is supposed to work among all pipelines might actually not work equally in all of them
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Keep up the good work! I really like the idea of a centralized set of best-practice pipelines

What do you like most about nf-core?: Collaborative programming & learning from experienced developers
What have been your biggest difficulties: The large and perhaps sometimes excessive amount of rules or good practices. This makes nf-core good, but not always easy for new members.
Any other feedback on nf-core?:
Would love to one day have within nf-core tools to be able to run standalone module (or subworkflows) pipelines - similar to bactopia

ie. `nf-core module run fastp -input `samplesheet.csv` -args '--trim_x ... ' -args2 'some_more_custom_args' -pipeline custom/repo/of/pipeline ` 
The custom/repo/of/pipeline is important for reproducibility purposes
I believe this will make nf-core pipelines appeal to a much wider applications. Also, the meta.yml files  can be used with nf-schema to validate the input samplesheet. 

Thx!

What do you like most about nf-core?: Discussions on slack
Any other feedback on nf-core?: It is great.

What do you like most about nf-core?: Simplicity of running jobs, configurability
What have been your biggest difficulties: Chaining two pipeline together
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Possibility to chain pipelines together,

What do you like most about nf-core?: Ease of use
learning and interacting
Easy to find the right pipeline and the tube diagrams make it easy to explain the steps to new users
What have been your biggest difficulties: Honestly haven't had many! Sometimes pipelines get very big and break on steps I don't care about, so maybe they should split into smaller pipelines if they get unwieldy?
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Long-read 16S metagenomics pipeline please!

What do you like most about nf-core?: Setting opinionated standards and frameworks for bioinformatic pipelines, including developer tooling. These kinds of things allow me to use nf-core content in non-nf-core pipelines, which makes all the content of nf-core a huge asset for bioinformatics at large.
What have been your biggest difficulties: While the opinionated standards previously mentioned are great, them being opinionated also means that they are not always perfect for all situations, which is fine. I have experienced, however, that it can be difficult being heard while voicing new ideas or changes to the standards, and I get the feeling that the standards are held close in the core team's hands. This is, in general, a good thing (i.e. having a core team with a clear vision), but I do feel the communication could become better - saying why a change is deemed bad/undesired, for example, rather than letting the discussion fade away in Slack.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: The nf-core community and all its content really is amazing! While I don't use the pipelines themselves that much, the modules are subworkflows are great additions to many of the projects I work with, and they really do speed up the development process. The latest template changes that allow greater granularity for inclusion/exclusion of various template parts is great, and I think continuing in this vein is the way to go: keep doing great pipelines with the nf-core standards, but facilitate people working with the nf-core tooling to make non-nf-core pipelines of their own. I feel that the modules really are the best part of nf-core overall, and allowing them to be used in external pipelines really does contribute immensely to bioinformatics at large.
Positive Tags: Collaborative policies, Template consistency, Modularity/sharing of components

What do you like most about nf-core?: Guiding/interaction through slack. Community events.
What have been your biggest difficulties: Organising the reviews of huuuuge pipeline PRs maybe? ( also fixing typos in their questionnaire :P )

What have been your biggest difficulties: Test suit, debugging

What do you like most about nf-core?: great documentation, helpful slack community

What do you like most about nf-core?: Fostering a community of users and developers
What have been your biggest difficulties: Keeping up to date. Every time I come back to the community there are large changes, though I know this is largely because both Nextflow and nf-core feed each other's development.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: It's a wonderful ecosystem. I think the challenge will be long-term maintenance of workflows and how to deal with those which lose developers. In other words what is the life cycle of the code, and what is the policy if there are no maintainers for a specific workflow?
Comments James: I guess need document how criteria/procedures for archiving pipelines (also how we select pipelines - better transparence on how core/maintainers works)

What do you like most about nf-core?: The helpful community
What have been your biggest difficulties: The standards being made around an unfinished DSL, which really needs time to mature first. Standards often seem to be based on philosophy over function/experience, and those guiding philosophies are themselves seemingly quite unique - development of "good practice" here seems to be somewhat divorced from historical programming standards. User-developers without a programming background are then learning from these standards, which makes it more difficult for sysadmins and programmers to successfully interface with these user-developers, and sets these users poorly for other programming tasks.
Improvement Tags: Communication, Opaque decision making, Overly strict standards

What do you like most about nf-core?: For rnaseq and mag, focusing on best practices and not adding too much bloat but going beyond the very basics. For more niche pipelines, the documentation is as valuable as the pipeline.
What have been your biggest difficulties: I use nfcore on a cluster that has no easy road to using singularity clusters because of their security review process. So I'm stuck using the mamba profile. Also, configuration is a nightmare. I tried for a long time to get nfcore mag to let me queue more than 100 jobs at a time on the cluster including overriding on the command line, never found where the configuration was being overridden.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: I'd love more micro pipelines and modularity. I often need to clean reads from shotgun metagenomics to use for a variety of things, but if I've already cleaned them its difficult to turn off all the steps I've done with nfcore mag.

What have been your biggest difficulties: I'm just learning about everything...so not in a position to comment at this time.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: none at this time

What do you like most about nf-core?: The community
What have been your biggest difficulties: I would like to see even more adoption of nf-core workflows as a standard in academia, especially in cores
Any other feedback on nf-core?: I would like to see nf-core workflows adopted in even more university core facilities, especially. This would apply to seqera platform, also. One, I of course think nf-core workflows are better than the alternatives. But, the more nf-core workflows become de facto standards for training institutions, the more likely it is that the become de facto standards everywhere else.

What do you like most about nf-core?: Don't know, I'm just starting
What have been your biggest difficulties: I didn't yet. Just starting

What do you like most about nf-core?: Pre-build modules

What do you like most about nf-core?: I'm a software developer by trade. nf-core brings all the good practices from software writing into nextflow pipelines (and I would even argue bioinformatics)

What do you like most about nf-core?: It is extremely powerful and doesn't need much to run

What do you like most about nf-core?: I like using the nf-core pipelines. They are very organized. Also thank you for organizing workshops and making them available on youtube. Very helpful!

What do you like most about nf-core?: The community and documented pipelines
What have been your biggest difficulties:
Adding custom configs for my team to use is easy to do, but ends up creating some edge-case bugs  that can be hard to debug. This is probably coming from a combination of nf-core pipeline design and Nextflow features.

Also, I run pipelines on an HPC, so I have had to download local copies of the Apptainer images for all the pipelines we use. This gets hard to manage since there isn't a great way to specify which subset of images to download (using the cli app). Mulled images (which I know should be going away) make it hard to figure out what pipeline they came from.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Thank you for making the pipelines available to the community. Also thanks to your slack channel.
Improvement Tags: Documentation (configs), HPC Installation and Setup, Offline support

What do you like most about nf-core?: Easy to use

What do you like most about nf-core?: modularity
What have been your biggest difficulties: negociating pipelines developments with community

What do you like most about nf-core?: Great community across pipelines, with a lot of knowledge sharing and a  genuine passion/desire to contribute to creating robust, reproducible pipelines.
What have been your biggest difficulties: Nf-core pipelines/templates are very well thought through, and there is fantastic tooling to support their development. That said, they can be quite overwhelming for nextflow beginners to grasp and debug.

What have been your biggest difficulties: I'm still learning and haven't been around long enough to make a fair assessment!

What do you like most about nf-core?: The immediate replies to my questions. Very kind and very detailed answers!

What do you like most about nf-core?: welcoming community, accessible trainings

What do you like most about nf-core?: The outstanding community support

What do you like most about nf-core?: The community support, help, and responsiveness. The adoption of standards as much as possible. The continuous improvement on modules and the codebase.

What do you like most about nf-core?: Support using the pipeline is really good.

What do you like most about nf-core?: The repeatability, reliance and helping community. Also the available tools for developing new pipelines and adapting existing ones.

What do you like most about nf-core?: Best part is rescue option to start the run where it got interrupted, rather to start the program from scratch
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Excellent facilities and platform to discuss with super brain in their field and their inputs are always useful. However, I am waiting for fusion calling for single cell data. We have lot of tools and pipeline for fusion calling with bulk RNAseq

What do you like most about nf-core?: The ability to quickly and easily run different modalities

What do you like most about nf-core?: The support from the community
What have been your biggest difficulties: Debugging pipelines and developing complex features

What do you like most about nf-core?: The community. I like a lot people working in Seqera and how helpful and approachable. And whole community around nf-core is really optimistic, smart and innovative. Second thing is pool of pipeline that can easy be used and adopt for specific application.

What do you like most about nf-core?: I appreciate the efforts to make pipelines available to a wide variety of users.  The developers are very engaged and helpful on Slack.
What have been your biggest difficulties: The main problem is the complexity of the pipelines and the cryptic nature of many of the error messages.  I assume this is primarily a java/groovy issue, and I'm not a java programmer. I'm not sure what the solution is, but that is the most frustrating thing about nf-core, the fact that the pipelines sometimes fail and its very difficult to figure out why and/or to fix what went wrong.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Higher consistency of pipeline completion, but I know that is much easier said than done.

What do you like most about nf-core?: User centricity
What have been your biggest difficulties: Getting started

What do you like most about nf-core?: The consistent, modular structure is very easy to work with once I understood it
What have been your biggest difficulties: Learning the language, though I'm still a relatively new to bioinformatics. And right now, incorporating software not available from conda

What do you like most about nf-core?: putting together useful modules into a robust pipeline for RNA-seq
What have been your biggest difficulties: I have a programming background but have been out of that field for about a decade. Now I want to write scripts to analyze my biomedical research data. The onslaught of new terminology (apptainer, github, mamba, etc etc) that are assumed to be "known" has been a barrier. Getting started with using nf-core on our HPC has also been challenging as our sysadmins are also just learning it. It is not enough to follow the instructions online and sometimes there is conflicting info (eg, use conda or not). Which config file to use and which directory to put it in, etc. It would be amazing to have a visual representation (flowchart) of what is happening.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: please post more examples for newcomers to follow. Please make a "common problems" list as well. Thanks!
Improvement Tags: Documentation (newcomer developer), HPC Installation and Setup

What do you like most about nf-core?: Suite of tools and modules to help build Nextflow pipelines
What have been your biggest difficulties: The nf-core docs are useful but confusing to navigate and could benefit from adhering to the Diataxis framework https://diataxis.fr/

What do you like most about nf-core?: the community and simple look of the website
What have been your biggest difficulties: troubleshooting a failed run

What do you like most about nf-core?: community resources
What have been your biggest difficulties: More help/troubleshooting documents for specific modules. Especially those that are not currently in use by existing pipelines. I've found that I've had to edit nf-core modules to get them to work with my use cases. Ultimately not a huge deal to edit for my own needs , but would be nice to have more documentation around how to run modules 'out-of-the-box'
Any other feedback on nf-core?: More moderation on #help and #nostupidquestions. My questions (and others) go unanswered occasionally.

What do you like most about nf-core?: Contributing and interacting seems to me very strong points. I will have to get more acquainted with community to give a more reliable observation.
What have been your biggest difficulties: Personally for me it has difficult been interacting with nf-core as a user, even more so the thought of running it as a developer.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: I would be interested in helping with unit and component testing or finding other ways to help out with nf-core (documentation, comments etc.)

What do you like most about nf-core?: fair, reproducible, etc. working together. great procedures wrt to tests, template for developers. We know the story, nf-core is great, period
What have been your biggest difficulties: too frequent changes! hard to keep up

What do you like most about nf-core?: The community support and positivity. The curated pipelines. The frequency of hackathons and the youtube channel !
What have been your biggest difficulties: So far, finding time to actually develop using nextflow
Any other feedback on nf-core?: All is good. The socks work great ! Really easy plug and play :-P

What do you like most about nf-core?: making pipelines visible, standardized and non-redundant
Nice to have state of the art pipelines with all the appropriate quality controls that run easily on a cluster.
The ability to tap into a bioinformatics hive-mind
What have been your biggest difficulties: contributing feels difficult, especially because of the testing, schema etc frameworks that often fail and solving issues seems close to impossible
Any other feedback on nf-core?: I would love some ribo-seq swag!

What do you like most about nf-core?: Ease of use, amount of pipelines
What have been your biggest difficulties: Contributing
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Reduce the boilerplate code for pipelines

What have been your biggest difficulties: Templates are updated and it isn't always immediately clear what these are and how they might affect the development of new non nf-core pipelines.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Really great community I'm glad to be a member of

What do you like most about nf-core?: Reusable modules and nfcore tools make writing pipelines super easy. Feedback on Slack is generally very quick.
What have been your biggest difficulties: Essentially, I think breaking changes are made way too often with little benefit to users and developers, just that it is "neater" or conceptually "nicer". For most developers nextflow and nf-core isn't their entire job so to keep up with the frequent changes is near impossible and burdensome. There should be more consideration for which changes are really bringing a lot of positive benefit to developers and/or users and perhaps better communication/documentation of the latest standards. As far as I'm aware I need to check one of the most maintained pipelines to understand the latest standards.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Keep up the great work!
Positive Tags: Modularity/sharing of components, Speed of responses
Improvement Tags: Tool release speed, Template complexity, Communication

What do you like most about nf-core?: I use nf-core pipelines (their software choices and containers) as inspiration for my own pipelines
What have been your biggest difficulties: nf-core pipelines tend to be extremely complex. It takes a lot of time to understand how to apply them and how the code works.

What do you like most about nf-core?: Open source high end tools
What have been your biggest difficulties: Configuring to work with different cloud environments
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Great community - It would be great to see closer ties with local and international movements like Global Alliance for Genomic Health and Genomics England. Ultimately working towards genomic standards for further clinical use of the tools.

What do you like most about nf-core?: I really like the community support and the tools made for the developer.
What have been your biggest difficulties: I have some trouble with the standardisation of the modules (names of inputs, terminology). The test datasets repository is really complicated to use with many duplicate and not a lot of information.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: I have trouble to convince people in France to contribute to nf-core, but this seems to be a cultural problematic.

What do you like most about nf-core?: pipelines are easy to set up for beginners, extensive and helpful documentation, the nf-core slack channels are extremely helpful resources and create a welcoming community
What have been your biggest difficulties: It's not obvious what resources are appropriate for each pipeline - my university HPC cluster charges us based on the resources that we request for each job, so I'd appreciate if I can easily find the minimum resources required for each pipeline and not be overly generous.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: I appreciate your great work!
Positive Tags: Ease of use, Documentation/training, Community feel, Inclusivity

What do you like most about nf-core?: Modularity
What have been your biggest difficulties: Installing local/unpublished modules/workflows

What do you like most about nf-core?: Providing tools open source and in a centralised manner to reduce the amount of repeated work for researchers and developed
What have been your biggest difficulties: There are many standards and tools through nf-core which are not always followed in different pipelines. Would help if there was a clearer connection for new devs to prevent them from re-implementing existing techniques. E.g. There are many modules in nf-core/proteinfold which are set up in ways very differently to the nf-core/modules standards.
Any other feedback on nf-core?: Thank you for maintaining this great community and set of tools.

What do you like most about nf-core?: Everything, it's helping me get a community within the field that I am passionate about.
What have been your biggest difficulties: Nothing so far

It is uncomfortable to try to contribute and then get rejected, but the rules or the criteria is not clear (at least to newcomers).

What do you like most about nf-core?: Support and Ease of use

What do you like most about nf-core?:
- Promoting open science
- Fostering community spirit, welcoming and low barrier to entry, memes.
What have been your biggest difficulties:
- Understanding different design philosophies used by different pipelines/components.
- Keeping up with changes to core components.
- Troubleshooting via slack search sometimes leads to rabbit holes or difficulties to assess whether a problem still exists or was solved somewhere in the meantime.
- Related to previous point, mismatches between documentation, slack, GitHub PR/issue info, obsolete pages turned up via google and conflicts/redundancies between different pages of the website.
Any other feedback on nf-core?:
- Stay awesome and transparent. Try to do good. Be kind.
- So far it seems to be working great, but a danger with these kinds of initiatives could be evolving into an inside-club (or at least seeming like one to an outsider), which could turn people off who are more timid to join (which I guess is a general problem with mostly online communities).
Improvement Tags: Variable pipeline quality, Communication, Use of slack, Tool release speed, Documentation (writing pipelines)

What do you like most about nf-core?: FAIR principles
What have been your biggest difficulties: Adapting to in-house HPC

What do you like most about nf-core?: very well documented and maintained
What have been your biggest difficulties: learning the nextflow way and setup in my on-premises servers

What do you like most about nf-core?: I liked how everyone was willing to help when I first started developing. As an undergraduate student who developed for nf-core during a summer internship, the opportunity to be collaborating with professionals around the globe in a way that I was significantly contributing while also benefitting from the community's expertise was an amazing experience.
What have been your biggest difficulties: nf-test syntax is a bit awkward. Also, a guide for using/developing for nf-core without access to a larger scale computing pipelines would be nice. Especially since the resource limits syntax was changed, it can be difficult to contribute with limited computing resources, but I am sure there are other students out there who would be glad to do so if there was some more guidance on creating test-sized datasets and running/using nf-core pipelines on personal computers

What do you like most about nf-core?: Community shared modules and development tools

Using the nf-core ecosystem (modules / dev tools ) without developing a complete nf-core workflow. 

I think there are a lot of use cases where you do not want to develop a full nf-core workflow but still use all the dev tools. Documentation is also lacking on how to use nf-core just for modules.
